title: Will other people need to sign up for Filecanvas or Dropbox to access my canvases?
body:
No. For others to view your canvas, all they need is the web address of the canvas.

The web address for a canvas takes the form https://${username}.filecanvas.com/${sitename}, where ${username} is your Filecanvas username and ${sitename} is your canvas path (as specified in your account settings page and the canvas's settings page).

These links can be shared with anybody, however you can choose to password-protect your sites to keep them private.

title: Where are my canvases stored?
body:
Filecanvas does not store any of your files. All the files in your canvases are located on Dropbox's secure file servers.

By default, whenever you create a canvas, Filecanvas will create a new canvas folder within a folder named filecanvas inside your Dropbox. Your canvas will then stay in sync with the contents of this folder.

title: Can I invite others to collaborate on a canvas?
body: Absolutely. You can use Dropbox's shared folders feature to share a canvas's folder with other Dropbox users. Any changes they make to the folder contents will be reflected in the canvas.

title: Is there a limit to how many canvases I can create from one account?
body: During the beta phase, you can create as many canvases as you want. Please be aware that this is likely to change once the beta phase ends.

title: Where did my files go? My canvas is suddenly empty!
body:
Sounds like either you've moved or renamed your folder within your Dropbox, or you've revoked Filecanvas's access to your Dropbox.

If you've moved or renamed your canvas folder, you can either move the folder back to its original location (within the filecanvas folder in your Dropbox), or you can update your canvas's Linked folder setting in the canvas settings page to match the folder's new location.

If you've accidentally revoked Filecanvas's access to your Dropbox folder, just log into Filecanvas and it will restore Filecanvas's access to your Dropbox.

title: Can I password-protect my canvases?
body:
Yes. Follow these steps to restrict access to a canvas:

  1. Go to your Dashboard, and click on the canvas that you want to password-protect
  2. Under the "Password protection" section, check the "Password protect this canvas" checkbox and save your changes
  3. Under the "Password protection" section, you can now edit the username/password combinations that can be used to access this canvas

title: Can I retrieve the password for a password-protected canvas?
body:
For security reasons, Filecanvas only stores an encrypted version of the passwords for the users on your password-protected canvases. This means that it's impossible to retrieve a user's password if it has been forgotten. It's very easy to reset a user's password though:

  1. Go to your Dashboard, and and click on the canvas
  2. Under the "Password protection" section, follow the link to edit the canvas's registered users
  3. Click the pencil icon next to the user and set a new password

title: Can I set a default canvas to display at my Filecanvas web root?
body: Yes. You can choose which canvas shows up as the default canvas for your Filecanvas web root (i.e. at https://${username}.filecanvas.com/) by changing the "Home canvas" setting in your account settings.

title: Can I change the username for my Filecanvas web root?
body: Yes. You can change your Filecanvas username in your account settings. Your web root address will update instantly, and any existing sites will now be accessible from your new web root address.

title: Can I move/rename my canvas folder within my Dropbox?
body:
Yes, however make sure to update the Linked folder path in your canvas settings accordingly, or it will appear as if there are no files in your canvas.

You can put your sites anywhere in your Dropbox, however it's recommended that canvas folders should be kept in a folder named filecanvas in your Dropbox root.

title: Can I use an existing folder as a canvas folder?
body: Yes. Make sure the folder is inside the filecanvas folder within your Dropbox, and then create a new canvas, making sure to set the Canvas name to the name of the folder.

title: Can I use my own domain name (e.g. http://www.example.com/) with Filecanvas?
body:
Yes. You can point your own domain names to your main Filecanvas web root, or to individual canvases. And don't worry: if you use your own custom domain name, the Filecanvas web address won't be displayed to the user.

To use a custom domain name, set up a CNAME alias as follows:

Example 1: Pointing your domain to your main Filecanvas web root
This example assumes your Filecanvas username is ${username}, you own the domain name example.com, and you want to point www.example.com to your Filecanvas web root
  1. Log in to your hosting provider's DNS settings page
  2. Add a CNAME alias entry that points from the www subdomain to ${username}.filecanvas.com. (including the trailing . character)
Once the DNS settings have updated, http://www.example.com should now be pointing to your web root at http://${username}.filecanvas.com/. This means that you will be able to access your canvases at http://www.example.com/${sitename} (where ${sitename} is the path to one of your canvases).
Example 2: Pointing your domain to an individual canvas
This example assumes your Filecanvas username is ${username}, you have a canvas with its path set to ${sitename}, you own the domain name example.com, and you want to point www.example.com to your canvas
  1. Log in to your hosting provider's DNS settings page
  2. Add a CNAME alias entry that points from the www subdomain to ${sitename}.${username}.filecanvas.com. (including the trailing . character)
Once the DNS settings have updated, http://www.example.com should now be pointing to your canvas at http://${username}.filecanvas.com/${sitename}

The examples above use the www subdomain, however you can set up a CNAME record for whichever subdomain you like (e.g. extranet or my.nested.subdomain). You can also use multiple CNAME records if you want to serve the canvas from multiple addresses.

title: Can I point my root domain (e.g. http://example.com/) to Filecanvas?
body: It depends on your DNS provider. Some DNS providers don't allow you to create a CNAME record for your root domain, so you might be better off setting up a CNAME record for the www subdomain that points to your canvas (see the instructions above), and using your DNS provider to set up a redirect from example.com to www.example.com. Alternatively, you can switch to a different DNS provider such as CloudFlare that allows you to set up a CNAME record on your root domain.

title: Can I use SSL for custom domains?
body: All canvases on filecanvas.com are served via https, however the Filecanvas SSL certificate won't be valid for your custom domain names. Get in touch if you need SSL support for custom domains.
